#### Section 3: Batteries
A future society based on abundant, renewable energy sources such as
from wind and solar require a place to store the energy once it is
generated. The reason that storage is needed is that these sources are
intermittent. The wind isn't always blowing and the sun is really only
at its brightest from around 10 am to 4 pm. In contrast, fossil fuels
such as coal and natural gas can be burned whenever. Their physical form
solves the storage issue automatically. Thus, we need to find a way to
buffer electricity demand during the times in which energy from wind and
solar is not being generated.[^11.3.1] Many potential solutions have been
proposed, such as pumping water "uphill" or into dams and then releasing
it after the sun goes down to generate "on demand" hydroelectric power.
Indeed, this approach is gaining traction. Other solutions involve
converting excess energy generated during windy and sunny times into
chemical fuels, such as hydrogen, which when burned in an engine or
**fuel cell**[^11.3.2] can be used to generate electricity. However, perhaps
the most attractive mechanism for portable energy storage is by
manipulating electrochemical potentials. That is, batteries. Modern
battery technologies, exemplified in the now-ubiquitous lithium ion
type, are full of examples of nanoengineered systems. We examine the
basics, below.

### 11.3.1. Operation of batteries

A battery operates by manipulating the natural tendencies of some atoms,
molecules, or materials to want to give up electrons and the tendencies
of other materials to accept these electrons. Those species which give
up electrons are said to be **oxidized** in the process, while those
that accept electrons are said to be **reduced**.[^11.3.3] When electrons
flow from one **half cell** to the other, when connected by a wire, the
electrochemical potential can be captured to power a load. The battery
stops working when the two half cells are at thermodynamic equilibrium,
and there is no longer any tendency for electrons to go from one
material to the other. We explore the operation of a battery in more
detail, below.

#### Definitions

A battery comprises two **half-cells**---an oxidation half-cell and a
reduction half-cell. The oxidation half-cell consists of a material with
a strong tendency to give up electrons and the reduction half-cell is a
material that accepts these electrons. You may have heard the terms
**anode** and **cathode**. The anode is the site of oxidation and the
cathode is the site of reduction.[^11.3.4] The anode is thus the negatively
charged electrode and the cathode is the positively charged one.[^11.3.5] The
quintessential battery consists of one or more **galvanic cells**. A
galvanic or voltaic cell consists of two elemental metals with different
oxidation potentials. These metal **electrodes** are immersed in
separate beakers in **electrolyte solution**. The electrodes are
connected to a voltmeter or **load** (like a light bulb) using a wire.
The beakers are connected using a **salt bridge** which can be, for
example, a glass tube filled with a **hydrogel** saturated with a
solution of an inert salt.

The classic example of a galvanic cell has a zinc anode and a copper
cathode. The oxidation half reaction is

$$\text{Zn}^0 = \text{Zn}^{2+} + 2\text{e}^{-}$$

And the reduction half reaction is

$$\text{Cu}^{2+} + 2\text{e}^{-} = \text{Cu}^0$$

For an overall reaction of

$$\text{Cu}^{2+} + \text{Zn}^0 = \text{Cu}^0 + \text{Zn}^{2+}$$

Once this system is in place, electrons flow from the zinc (which wants
to be oxidized) to the wire, through the load, to the copper (which
wants to be reduced). Charge neutrality must be maintained, otherwise a
huge excess of positive charge would build up at the anodic half cell
and vice versa. The system maintains charge neutrality by the drift of
ions through the salt bridge. In the example drawn in Figure (11.8), the
ions that migrate are sulfate.

(Figure 11.8) 
>>>image(zinc-copper.png.0)

The voltage of the cell can be determined by summing up the oxidation
potentials of the two half reactions. The electrochemical potential
energies of metals is tabulated in the form of the **reduction
potential**, not the oxidation potential. Thus the potential energy of
the whole cell is given by

$$E_{total} = E_{cathode}-E_{anode}$$

In this case, the standard reduction potential of zinc is -0.76 V and
the standard reduction potential of copper is 0.34 V. The total
potential of the galvanic cell is thus 1.10 V. When we say *standard*
reduction potential, we are making a reference to the **standard
hydrogen electrode**, which involves the reaction of two protons with
two electrons to form H$_2$, or hydrogen gas.

#### Key figures of merit: Power and energy

In modern technology, you may sometimes hear, in jest, the mantra
*better, faster, cheaper!*. For battery technologies, you could be a bit
more specific, and say *more energy density, more power density, safer,
lighter, and more earth-abundant*. There are other key figures of merit
as well.

**Energy density** refers to the total amount of potential energy that
can be stored in the electrochemical cells per unit mass. It is the
total capacity of the battery. For example, the lithium-ion batteries
inside electric vehicles might have a total capacity of 100
kilowatt-hours (kWh) or 360 megajoules (MJ).[^11.3.6] The capacity of the
battery in your phone is closer to 0.01 kWh.[^11.3.7]

**Power density** refers to the speed at which the energy can be
extracted from the battery. Power, in terms of watts, or joules per
second, is dependent on the molecular level processes occurring in the
electrochemical cells. That is, oxidation and reduction at the
electrodes, along with transport and diffusion of electrons and ions
between the two half-cells.

The energy and power densities are often expressed in terms of
**specific energy** and **specific power** in units of J kg$^{-1}$ or W
kg$^{-1}$. Note that these densities are per mass (gravimetric) not per
volume (volumetric). The specific energies and the specific powers for
energy storage devices are often regarded to be in competition. For
example, a capacitor can deliver power very quickly (think of a camera
flash), but cannot store very much energy because it can only hold a
thin layer of charge at the surface of metallic films. Alternatively, a
fuel cell which converts hydrogen to electricity discharges very slowly
but has a ton of potential energy stored in its chemical bonds (i.e., of
H$_2$). A convenient way to visualize the energy density and power
density is the Ragone (rah-GO-nee) plot, see Figure (11.9).

(Figure 11.9) 
>>>image(ragone.png.0)

Despite the strong correlation between specific energy and specific
power, there is still room for optimization. Much of this latitude is
afforded by, you guessed it, nanoengineering of the electrode materials.
We look at the special case of lithium ion batteries, below.

### 11.3.2. Lithium-ion batteries: materials selection

Lithium ion batteries operate by the movement of lithium ions (Li$^+$)
and electrons (e$^-$) between two half cells. One half cell, the anode,
contains graphite and lithium atoms (Li$^0$). The other half cell, the
cathode, contains lithium metal (often cobalt) oxide (see Figure
(11.10)). The two half cells are separated by a membrane electrolyte
which is permeable to lithium ions. In normal operation, when the cells
are fully charged, the lithium metal atoms on the anode side give up
their electrons. The graphite is connected to a copper film, which
itself is connected to a wire. The electron exits the anode into the
copper film and thence to a wire, where the current flow can be used to
power an electrical load. Meanwhile, the lithium ions traverse the
electrolyte **separator** to the cathode half-cell. The cathode
half-cell consists of an **intercalation compound**, of which the
archetype is lithium cobalt oxide (LiCoO$_2$). The cathode is supported
by a film of metal, typically aluminum. The electrons---after passing
through the wire connecting the two half cells---enter the cathode and
reduce the lithium ions back to lithium metal. When the battery is
(re)charged, a positive bias is applied to the cathode. Electrons leave
the lithium metal and the lithium ions that are created migrate back
over to the anode and take up residence between the graphene sheets of
the graphite anode.

(Figure 11.10) 
>>>image(lithium ion.png.0)

#### Anodes

The graphene sheets that make up the graphite are the perfect home for
the small lithium atoms. Recall that in a classical galvanic cell, the
metal ions either detach upon oxidation or deposit by reduction onto the
electrodes themselves. The metal electrodes either shrink or increase in
mass, depending on the direction of the flow of current. It is actually
the negatively charged counterion in the electrolyte solution that
migrates via the salt bridge to balance the excess of charge. In a
lithium-ion battery, the solid electrodes consist of graphite and
lithium cobalt oxide. Both materials are able to accommodate lithium
species within their solid structures. Thus, these materials can be
discharged and charged again while the changes to their structures are
nominally reversible.

Despite its popularity as an anode material, graphite has a somewhat low
specific capacity, owing to its low volumetric change upon lithiation.
In contrast, silicon can undergo a very large increase in volume
(5$\times$) and thus accommodate many more lithium atoms. Challenges to
the use of silicon anodes are indeed related to this large and
reversible volumetric change. This cycling in size can lead to cracking,
and thus polymeric binders that are permeable to ions must be
engineered. Nevertheless, silicon anodes are used in the commercial
market, with increased specific charge associated with, for example,
greater range in electric vehicles.

#### Cathodes

The conventional cathode of lithium cobalt oxide is known as an
**intercalation compound**, which means that some species---in this case
lithium atoms---can slide into the crystal structure. These materials
are selected for various applications on the basis of either total
capacity of charge storage or the speed with which the charges can be
extracted. For example, while cathodes based on lithium cobalt oxide
might be the best for relatively low-power devices like smartphones and
laptops, they may not be the best for electric vehicles, which require a
lot of power quickly. Researchers are constantly looking for new types
of intercalation compounds that can shuttle ions in and out of their
crystal structures quickly.

### 11.3.3. Case study: electric vehicles

Indeed the ability to move lithium ions and atoms in and out of the
electrodes is hugely important for the electrification of the economy.
Much of the energy usage associated with carbon emissions and thus
global climate change comes through the transportation sector of the
economy. Electric vehicles (EVs) are expected to take a majority of the
market share of new vehicles sold in the United States by around
2030-2035. The expectation of huge growth is supported by (1)
environmental regulation, (2) consumer tax incentives, and (3) the fact
that many aspects of ownership of EVs are superior to those of vehicles
powered by an **internal combustion engine (ICE)**. The electrification
of the transportation sector of the economy is intimately tied to the
development of strategies for the electrochemical storage of
energy---i.e., batteries. As you know, batteries have been used in
automobiles for many decades. Headlights, radios, and power windows have
always required electricity. Nevertheless, the movement of vehicles
weighing thousands of pounds over ranges of hundreds of miles has
required the development of new types of battery technologies.

#### Oldie but goodie: The lead-acid battery

Vehicles have had electrical components for around a century.
Headlights, indoor lighting, audio equipment, and operation of the
instrument clusters use a **lead-acid** battery (starting, lighting, and
ignition, the "SLI" tasks). The lead acid battery was invented in the
mid-nineteenth century, and was the first **rechargeable** battery to be
discovered. It may be surprising to learn that essentially all low
(12-volt) applications in automobiles are still powered by the lead-acid
battery, and to this day this ancient technology represents around 50%
of the market share of batteries sold in the world.

A lead-acid battery consists of an elemental (i.e., metallic) lead
electrode separated by an electrolyte, sometimes a gel, containing
sulfuric acid. The cathode consists of lead oxide (PbO$_2$). In
operation, excess electrons travel from the metallic lead through an
external wire to power the peripheral devices of the car. The lead oxide
is reduced by the electrons returning to the cathode. During this
reduction reaction, an oxygen ion (O$^{2-}$) is ejected. It quickly
picks up two acidic hydrogen ions (protons) from the sulfuric acid, and
becomes water. The naked sulfate ion that is produced migrates through
the liquid or gel electrolyte to the anode, where the lead atoms that
lost their two electrons combine with the sulfate to become lead
sulfate. (Actually, both the anode and the cathode when fully discharged
become lead sulfate.) The equilibration of the electrochemical
potentials leads to a **dead battery**. The **alternator** of the car
turns excess mechanical energy into electrical potential that is used to
recharge the battery.

It is tempting to think of the architecture of the lead acid battery as
a textbook galvanic cell with wires connected to thick slabs of lead and
lead oxide separated by an electrolyte. In reality, however, a car
battery has a hierarchical structure. The anodes and cathodes are made
into thin plates covered by a nanoporous separator membrane that allows
ions through prevents contact and thus short circuiting of the
electrodes. Groups of plates are slid into place in an interdigitated
structure like two combs or the opposing sides of a zipper. In this
structure, the anode and cathode materials alternate. The purpose of
this structure is to increase the total surface area to permit facile
charging and discharging. The space between the interdigitated
electrodes is filled with an aqueous solution of sulfuric acid. Other
structures---e.g., concentric cylinders---are used for other
applications.

Each cell in a lead-acid battery has a nominal voltage of 2.1 V. To
achieve a total voltage of 12 V, six of these cells are connected in
series, with the negative terminal (anode) of one cell connected to the
positive terminal (cathode) of the next. The lead-acid battery is
capable of around 500 full discharge cycles before it must be replaced.
The finite lifetime of a lead-acid battery is the result of the
formation of a crystallized form of lead sulfate that forms at both the
anode and the cathode which, unlike amorphous lead sulfate, does not
revert back to the pure lead and lead oxide phases when recharged. Once
this unwanted process of **sulfation** is completed, the battery is
dead.

#### The lithium-ion "traction" battery

All hybrid, plug-in hybrid, and fully electric vehicles also have a
larger, more powerful battery on board. This is the so-called **traction
battery**, because it is used not to power the ignition and the
relatively low-power lights and peripherals in the passenger cabin, but
the wheels. The fact that electric vehicles even had two batteries for
different purposes was made strikingly clear to me on a recent camping
trip in Cuyamaca Rancho State Park near San Diego. In order to unload
our food, drinks, tent, and other accessories, we left the lift gate of
our plugin hybrid vehichle open, and didn't close it for several hours.
Unbeknownst to me, the opening of the lift gate engaged all kinds of
electronic circuits in the inside of the car. I had believed that the 10
kWh battery---half full at the time we parked---would make the phrase
"dead battery" a thing of the past, at least for drivers of cars with
big lithium ion batteries. It turns out that this battery has a highly
specialized purpose, and that it is to power the wheels, and little
else. Apparently, the lead-acid battery needs to have charge even to
turn the car on! By leaving the lift gate open, I had depleted the
lead-acid battery and the car would not even start. Thankfully, we had a
12-volt battery pack with us that we had purchased to jump a different
car left unused in our garage during the COVID-19 pandemic. We had
brought this battery to charge our USB devices, and were able to use it
to start the car.

Lithium-ion batteries, along with functionally equivalent
lithium-polymer batteries (which use a polymeric electrolyte), have
higher energy densities than lead-acid batteries and also longer
lifetimes. They can in general be discharged deeper with less
degradation in capacity. Traction batteries with capacities of 200 V can
be produced by combining many **cells** with nominal voltages of 3 to 4
V in various arrangements into the **battery pack**. Lithium-ion
batteries are considered a technology of moderate maturity, which means
that there are many avenues for potential discovery and improvement.

### 11.3.4. Areas for discovery

Battery technologies---and in particular those based on the lithium-ion
concept---are still in a rich phase of research and development. Many
university and industrial laboratories are working to increase the power
density, energy density, lifetime, safety, recyclability, and
environmental burden of the components. Here, we highlight a few areas
which represent potentially fruitful avenues which are receiving
significant attention and research funding.

#### The solid electrolyte interface

One of the chief reasons that a lithium-ion battery loses its capacity
over its lifetime is because of unwanted reactions at the surface of the
anode. These reactions occur because of the high reduction potential of
the anode and thus its ability to react with molecules within the
electrolyte. Eventually, this process leads to the formation of a crusty
substance at the surface of the anode. This crust contains many types of
compounds and a composition and morphology that depends on the identity
of the molecules in the electrolyte. This crust is called the **solid
electrolyte interface (SEI)**. The formation of the SEI is regarded as
inevitable, but it is nevertheless the object of intense study.
Characterization of the compounds that form at the SEI and examination
of the way in which the compounds within the battery influence its
morphology could lead to better selection of materials or architecture
of the device. In particular, designs that slow the growth of the SEI or
allow its growth to proceed in a more predictable manner are desirable.

There are several ways in which the SEI has undesirable consequences on
the performance of a lithium-ion battery over time. For example, as the
anode reduces the molecules of the electrolyte---often carbonate
solvents---electron-rich products are formed. To balance the charge,
positively charged lithium ions become incorporated in these products.
The formation of these lithium-containing compounds is irreversible and
leads to a reduction in **lithium inventory** in the cell. Since lithium
atoms and ions are the currency of the battery, sequestration of lithium
in the SEI is equivalent to taking money out of the economy by putting
it under your mattress and then forgetting about it. Another way in
which the SEI reduces the effectiveness of the battery is by blocking
the migration of lithium into and out of the anode. This characteristic
of the SEI may reduce the power density. A final way in which the SEI
acts to reduce the efficiency of the battery may be counterintuitive.
That is, the SEI may be electrically conductive. Greater conductivity of
electrons means a greater rate of unwanted electrochemical reduction of
the compounds making up the electrolyte. This increase leads to greater
growth rate of the SEI, and thus a greater degradation of the
electrolyte, loss of lithium inventory, decreased rate of lithium
exchange with the anode, and so on. Thus, understanding the composition
of the SEI, its material properties, and methods to limit its formation
are key to increased usage of lithium-ion batteries in transportation
and grid-scale energy storage.

#### Alternative anode materials

Graphite has been the go-to anode material for its ability to house
lithium atoms in between its layers of graphene sheets. However, the
theoretical capacity of graphite to store lithium is limited to a single
lithium atom per six carbon atoms (LiC$_6$). This stoichiometry
corresponds to a specific charge capacity of 372 mAh g$^{-1}$, assuming
one electron per lithium atom. However, silicon has the ability to take
up a substantially greater amount of lithium in its crystal structure,
with a maximum of nearly four lithium atoms per silicon atom
(Li$_{3.75}$Si), and a specific capacity of 3,600 mAh g$^{-1}$. However,
with this ability to eat such large amounts of lithium, silicon gets
bloated. The periodic volumetric expansion of the anode upon charging
and discharging (up to 320% expansion) imposes significant mechanical
strains on the structure of the device. The silicon must be made into
nanowires or nanoparticles in order to accommodate the volumetric
expansion without cracking, but changing the form factor of the silicon
is not without its own challenges, as the "breathing" of these particles
still have the potential to disrupt the interior structure of the cell.
Attempts to mitigate the volumetric expansion have included the use of
carbon containing binders between silicon nanoparticles to increase the
mechanical stability, however cracking still occurs. Conductive polymers
incorporated into gels which absorb the mechanical work energy
associated with lithiation of silicon have recently shown some success.
These polymeric and gel-like binders must obviously be conductive to
lithium ions. This requirement imposes some additional constraints on
what materials can be used. Despite these challenges, silicon anodes are
highly desirable, and an effective strategy is to split the difference
between stability and charge capacity, and to use a mixture of graphite
and silicon.

#### Alternative cathode materials

In a lithium-ion battery, the anode and cathode have a similar function:
to store lithium atoms (Li$^0$) or ions (Li$^{+}$), respectively. Such
materials permit these lithium species to **intercalate** within their
crystal structures. The most well known intercalation compound for use
as the cathode is lithium cobalt oxide. Compared to alternatives
including lithium nickel oxide and nickel-cobalt-aluminum oxides,
LiCoO$_2$ has a lower capacity for lithium ions, but is more stable at
high-temperature operation. Unfortunately, it is still susceptible to
runaway oxidation of the electrolyte, which is highly exothermic, and
can lead to fires. Additionally, cobalt is known as a **conflict
mineral**. Its extraction---much of which is performed in the Democratic
Republic of Congo---is associated with resource conflict and
environmental degradation. Moreover, some mining organizations have been
found to be in abuse of child labor. Alternative cathode materials are
thus under intense investigation; the target being structures made from
elements with greater natural abundance (e.g., manganese) and which are
less susceptible to runaway oxidation and fires.

#### Metal ions

Lithium has many advantages as a repository of electrons and for its
ability to intercalate into graphite, silicon, and intercalation
compounds used at the cathode. However, lithium is relatively rare
compared to other alkali metals, and ancillary metals used in lithium
ion batteries---primarily copper, cobalt, and nickel---suffer from high
cost, scarcity, and other **negative externalities** of production.
Sodium-ion batteries operate on the same principle as their
lithium-based counterparts, but with the advantage that sodium is
ubiquitous. Consider that the ocean---a staggeringly huge amount of
liquid---is more than 1% sodium ions, by mass! One can immediately see
why this small-continent amount of sodium would be so attractive for use
in batteries.

Nevertheless, sodium is much larger than lithium, and thus it is more
difficult to achieve high energy densities with sodium than it is with
lithium.[^11.3.8] The difference in size between sodium and lithium require
the use of different electrode materials. For example, instead of
graphite, the anode for sodium ion batteries often uses a different
allotrope of carbon called **hard carbon**, i.e., charcoal. Hard carbon
is produced by heating certain types of polymers, including **lignin**,
carbohydrates, and other precursors in the absence of oxygen at around
1000 $^{\circ}$ C. What results is a highly porous, amorphous material
that differentiates itself from other carbonaceous allotropes in that it
cannot be converted to graphite.[^11.3.9] Hard carbon is capable of
incorporating sodium ions into its structure. Transfer of sodium in and
out of the solid is made easier by the fact that hard carbon is highly
porous.

As in lithium-ion batteries, cathodic materials for their sodium-based
alternatives also take the form of intercalation compounds. One of the
apparent advantages of sodium-ion technology is that the cathode
materials have the potential to use metals other than cobalt or nickel.
For example, sodium metal oxides in which the metal is either iron or
manganese---highly earth-abundant compared to cobalt and nickel---have
capacities comparable to those of common cathodes used in lithium-ion
batteries.

#### Section 2: Catalysis
Catalysis, as you may remember from your high school chemistry class, is
the process by which a chemical reaction is sped up. In particular, in a
catalytic process, the **activation energy** of a chemical reaction is
reduced. The activation energy is the "hill" of potential
energy---analogous to how your gravitational potential energy rises when
you climb a hill---that a reaction "passes over" on its way from
reactants to products. This reduction in activation energy leads to an
accelerated reaction rate compared to the rate of the uncatalyzed
reaction. Critically, the potential energies of the products and
reactants are the same; all that changes is the pathway to get there
(see Figure (11.1)). Catalysts work by making one or both components
more reactive, stabilizing the transition state, or bringing the
reactants in close proximity. Catalysts are also sometimes chemically
altered in the process, though this alteration is temporary. Catalysts
are typically used in a sub-stoichiometric amount, meaning a **loading**
of a few percent or less, compared to the number of molecules of the
reactants. Catalysts can be used in such small loadings since a single
catalyst molecule or catalytic site on a surface can be used again and
again. The number that quantifies the number of reactions affected by a
catalyst is the **turnover number**.

(Figure 11.1) 
>>>image(catalysis.png.0)

### 11.2.1. Homogeneous vs. heterogeneous catalysis

Catalysts can be literally any chemical species, from a reactive site in
a porous mineral to a large enzyme. Even a single proton can be a
catalyst. In attempting to classify the broad range of molecules and
materials that have catalytic function, the first distinction can be
made by whether they are dissolved in solution---**homogeneous
catalysts**---or supported by a solid surface or
particle---**heterogeneous catalysts**. Biological catalysts---generally
enzymes---share features of both homogeneous and heterogeneous
catalysts, and are often treated as occupying a third category.

#### Homogeneous catalysis

Homogeneous catalysts largely consist of isolated atomic and molecular
species. They include protons, organocatalysts, and transition metal
complexes. They are added to the reaction mixture along with the
starting materials in a solvent that can dissolve both the
**substrate(s)** and the catalyst. Such catalysts are sometimes
**organometallic** molecules consisting of a metal center surrounded by
organic **ligands**. Often, these molecules are called **transition
metal complexes** because the metal atoms or ions are usually transition
metals (occupying that long stretch of the periodic table between the
alkali and alkali earth metals on the left, to the "main group" on the
right, which contains carbon, sulfur, oxygen, nitrogen, silicon, and so
forth). That is, they belong to the class of elements with incompletely
filled $d$ orbitals.[^11.2.1] See Figure (11.2) for examples of famous
catalysts based on transition metal complexes. Advantages of homogeneous
catalysts include high selectivity in terms of the type of chemical
reaction that occurs, where on the substrate molecule it occurs, and the
suppression of side reactions. This selectivity arises from the fact
that every catalyst molecule is identical. (In contrast, as we will see
below, the surfaces of heterogeneous catalysts have active sites which
can differ in structure from one to the next.)

(Figure 11.2) 
>>>image(transition metal complexes.png.0)

The scope of reactions that can be affected by homogeneous catalysts is
vast. For example, the formation of carbon-carbon bonds, the synthesis
of polymers (sometimes the catalyst also serves as the initiator), and
the transformation of one functional group to another. For example,
acids and/or bases---Arrhenius, Brønsted-Lowry, or Lewis
definition---catalyze nearly all transformations of carbonyl-containing
functional groups. One special power of homogeneous catalysts is the
ability to affect **stereoselective** reactions. That is, reactions
which can produce one or the other mirror image of a molecule.
Transition metal based catalysts often have **chiral ligands**, which
affect the direction from which the substrates may approach the
catalyst, and thus determine which **stereoisomer** is produced. Organic
catalysts---of which enzymes are a special type---also have this
property. See Figure (11.3) for examples of chiral molecules. That is,
molecules whose mirror images are actually different compounds because
they have different orientations in space.

(Figure 11.3) 
>>>image(enantiomers.png.0)

Homogeneous catalysts have one major drawback: they are difficult to
recover after the reaction. Whereas a heterogeneous catalyst is usually
a solid and can often be recovered simply by filtration, a homogeneous
catalyst is dissolved in solution and is difficult to separate from the
products and reactants. The difficulty in removing so as to reuse the
catalyst is compounded by the instability of the catalyst molecules.
That is, homogeneous catalysts with active sites containing transition
metal atoms or ions are often unstable to air and water. Thus, methods
of aqueous extraction are incompatible with this type of catalyst. In
fact, in most chemical processes involving homogeneous catalysts based
on metals, the catalyst is destroyed when the reaction is **quenched**
(meaning stoppage of the reaction by the addition of water, another a
polar solvent, or a specific chemical species which deactivates the
catalyst or the reactants). A homogeneous catalyst also generally
requires the use of a solvent, whereas heterogeneous systems can act
directly on neat liquids and mixtures of gases.

#### Heterogeneous catalysis

Heterogeneous catalysis means that there is more than one phase present
in the reaction mixture. The heterogeneous catalyst itself is usually a
solid, and can act upon substrates present in either the liquid (or
solution) or gas phase. Compared to the reactions affected by
homogeneous catalysts, the types of reactions brought about by
heterogeneous catalysts are somewhat more limited. For example,
oxidation and reduction reactions and simple functional group
transformations are relatively straightforward to accomplish. Highly
selective reactions---such as those that can synthesize only one mirror
image of a compound---are difficult to achieve. The lack of selectivity
comes from the random arrangement and shapes of active sites in
catalytic particles and surfaces. Whereas the shape of the active site
in every molecule of a homogeneous catalyst is identical, in a
heterogeneous catalyst, there is a range of shapes.

Nevertheless, the vast majority of transformations in chemical
manufacturing by sheer tonnage of products is accomplished using
heterogeneous processes. What heterogeneous catalysts lack in
selectivity and specificity, they make up for in recyclability and
throughput. For example, it is a simple matter to remove catalyst
particles from a suspension by filtration. Moreover, if the catalyst is
immobilized on the inside surface of a reaction vessel---as in a
catalytic converter in an automobile, see below---the catalyst need not
be removed at all. Under favorable circumstances, catalyst molecules
usually used in homogeneous settings can be immobilized on the surfaces
of polymeric microbeads. This approach preserves the selectivity of the
homogeneous catalyst with the recyclability of catalysts in
heterogeneous systems.

### 11.2.2. Chemical manufacturing

Catalysis is ubiquitous in chemical manufacturing. Almost no commodity
nor fine chemical compound (especially polymers, pharamaceuticals, and
other organic molecules) can be produced without the use of catalysts.
Products with useful levels of complexity just don't form on their own
without the lowering of the activation barriers by catalysts. In fact,
even most bulk, commodity chemicals (think mineral acids like sulfuric
acid) are produced using catalysts. Chemical "cracking" of longer-chain
hydrocarbons into shorter chain ones in the petrochemical industry is
performed using high heat and the use of catalysts. Carbon-carbon bonds
simply do not break by themselves, even if the products have lower
potential energy than the reactants. Such reactions are simply too slow,
because the activation energy barrier on the way from reactants to
products is too high.

Some of the industrial processes with the largest impacts on society are
in the form of chemical manufacturing using catalysts. Chemical refining
could not occur without significant help from catalysts. Polymers, along
with the chemical starting materials from which they arise, are
generated using catalytic processes. A synthetic drug molecule may have
been manufactured as the result of 10-20 synthetic steps, most of which
were catalyzed. However, one of the most important industrial process
produces a simple product---ammonia, NH$_3$---without which modern life
on planet earth would not be possible.

#### Haber-Bosch process

The element of nitrogen is required for nearly everything, from the
production of fertilizers in agriculture to the synthesis of nitric acid
for the manufacturing of explosives. However, most nitrogen is locked up
in the atmosphere as nitrogen gas, dinitrogen (N$_2$), one of the most
inert gases known. It might as well be a noble gas! For decades,
nitrogen was obtained from mineral salts such as niter (KNO$_3$).
Alternatively, it could be extracted from guano (literally, bat poop) in
tropical caves. With the spreading of the industrial revolution,
large-scale agriculture, and the need for weapons for World War I, the
demand for nitrogen atoms became intense.

It was in this climate that Fritz Haber invented what became known as
the **Haber Process**, which generates ammonia from dinitrogen and
hydrogen gas. In the first sequence of reactions, many of which employ
heterogeneous catalysts, hydrogen is generated. This hydrogen is reacted
(again with the help of heterogeneous catalysts) with dinitrogen from
the air to produce ammonia. Ammonia is a highly valuable product, as it
can be used as the nitrogen source for a wide range of chemical
transformations. It is such an important compound industrially that it
consumes a vast amount of the world's energy resources: 1 percent of the
energy and 1.5 percent of carbon dioxide emissions.

### 11.2.3. Catalysis in biology

Biology is the ultimate proof-of-concept for the power and versatility
of catalysis, and of nanoengineering more broadly. From simple starting
materials---carbon dioxide, nitrogen, oxygen, and energy from sunlight
(and in some cases hydrothermal vents in the deep ocean---all of
biological structure and diversity is achieved. Metabolism, sensation,
reproduction, self-healing, consciousness, creativity, and all other
animal characteristics are all ultimately products of biochemical
processes. Thus, biology itself serves as a model for what systems of
highly selective nanostructured catalysts can do.

#### Enzymes

In the 1980s, visionary scientist Dr. K. Eric Drexler envisioned a
future dominated by molecular assemblers---nanoscopic machines akin to
industrial robots, but which could assemble molecules and ultimately
materials and devices atom by atom. The idea of a molecular assembler
stirred the imagination of many readers and was really a boon to the
field of nanotechnology. However, the idea was met with derision by
others. For example, some chemists point to the fact that chemical
reactions are required to transfer one atom to another. Moreover, such
reactions are done routinely on the scale of many tonnes with high
selectivity. Physical chemist and Nobel laureate Richard Smalley pointed
to the "sticky fingers" of a molecular assembler, by which he meant that
it would be difficult to detach atoms from the assembler to the
substrate because of strong van der Waals interactions. The strongest
criticism, however, comes from biology, where catalysts based on folded
proteins and nucleic acids---**enzymes** and **ribozymes**---already
have many of the characteristics of molecular assemblers. We explore the
properties of this extraordinarily important class of catalysts, here.

Essentially all chemical transformations carried out inside biological
systems are made possible by enzymes.[^11.2.2] Enzymes are the primary type
of biological catalyst, and are made primarily of proteins. Like other
proteins, enzymes have a **primary structure** consisting of a sequence
of amino acids, a **secondary structures** consisting of
$\alpha$-helices and $\beta$-sheets, a **tertiary structure** consisting
of disulfide bonds between cysteine residues (called a cystine disulfide
bond), and a **quaternary structure** consisting of multiple polypeptide
subunits stuck together.

The part of the enzyme that binds the **substrate(s)** is called the
**active site**, Figure (11.4). The active site, as in any catalyst,
must immobilize the reactant(s), affect a chemical change, and then
release the products. Just like any catalyst, an enzyme might undergo a
conformational reorganization and/or chemical change during the process,
but such a change is temporary. The hallmark of a catalyst is that it is
unchanged before and after the reaction it facilitates, so that it can
be used again and again. The active site has a shape that is
complementary to the shape of the transition state between reactants and
products. Inside the active site, the range of chemical functionality
afforded by the backbone of a polypeptide chain and on the R groups of
the amino acids are exploited to the fullest extent possible. That is,
lone pairs of oxygen atoms in the carbonyl groups and N--H groups along
the backbone, formal negative charges of aspartate and glutamate
residues, and formal positive charges of lysine, arginine, and histidine
residues, can be used to bond electrostatically to substrates. These
interactions are used to immobilize reactants in the active site, but
also to bring them in a position where they are more likely to react to
form products.

(Figure 11.4) 
>>>image(active site.png.0)

We note that the electrostatic interactions between an enzyme and its
substrate(s) tend to be stronger than suggested by the van der Waals
component consisting of dipole-dipole interactions given in Chapter 2.
The reason is that van der Waals forces assume the freedom for the
molecules containing permanent dipoles to rotate. This free rotation has
the effect of reducing the overall interaction energy between molecules
with permanent dipoles. Hence, the dipole-dipole force depends on
temperature, as a greater temperature unlocks a greater range of
orientations that a dipole can adopt in an electric field. However, when
a molecule is immobilized by multiple electrostatic and steric
interactions---like a key in a lock---it is no longer able to rotate
freely. Elimination of free rotation makes the electrostatic
interactions dominate even the London dispersion interaction, which we
told you in Chapter 2 was the dominant component of the van der Waals
interaction for all but the smallest molecules with strong dipole
moments. Thus, once a substrate is in the active site, it is locked in
tightly.

One of the aspects of the active site which affects its ability to
catalyze reactions is its shape. As it happens, the shape of the active
site is complementary not to the reactant(s) or product(s), but rather
to the shape of the **transition state**. Remember, the purpose of an
enzyme---or any catalyst, for that matter---is to lower the potential
energy of the transition state. The energy of the transition state is
directly related to the speed of the reaction by the Arrhenius equation,
equation (11.1), below

(Equation 11.1) $$k=A\exp{\frac{-E_{a}}{RT}}$$

where $E_a$ is the activation energy. Thus, by making itself
complementary to the transition state, the total electrostatic potential
energy can be lowered and the reaction rate will increase. Figure (11.4)
shows a schematic diagram of the shape of the active site and its effect
on the electrostatic potential energy of the transition state. The rate
of reaction of an enzyme is often characterized by the method of
Michaelis and Menten: Michaelis-Menten kinetics. While we will not go
into the topic here, you will learn all about it if you take a course in
biochemistry.

#### Industrial biocatalysis

Biological enzymes are used ubiquitously in industrial processes. One
example we will highlight is in **chiral resolution**. For example, the
enzyme lipase[^11.2.3] catalyzes the formation of ester bonds from carboxylic
acids and hydroxyl groups. When I (Darren) was an undergraduate
researcher, my project was to synthesize a natural product called
"basiliskamide A." This molecule was originally isolated from a
bacterium that lived inside a sea sponge (or something) off the coast of
Papua New Guinea. When new natural products are discovered, they are
often screened against an array of bacteria and other disease targets.
Basiliskamide A (Figure (11.5), along with its related isomer,
basiliskamide B) was found to have activity against two types of
fungi---*Aspergillus fumigatus* and *Candida albicans*. These two fungi
are not very dangerous to people with healthy immune systems (*C
albicans* causes diaper rash, which we've all had at some point in our
lives), but for those with weakened immune systems (e.g., HIV-AIDS
patients, chemotherapy patients, etc.), infections can be deadly.

(Figure 11.5) 
>>>image(basiliskamides.png.0)

Basiliskamide a is a pretty small, unassuming natural product. You
wouldn't base an entire PhD thesis on making it from scratch. But, it
was a good project for an undergraduate. However, there was a highly
challenging aspect to the synthesis. Namely, the series of four
**stereogenic centers** located in the red box in Figure (11.5). The
laboratory in which I did my undergraduate research specialized in
making these linear sequences of **stereogenic** carbon atoms.[^11.2.4] All
the atoms need to be attached in precisely the right way, otherwise the
molecule will cease to have its biological activity.

In order to generate stereogenic centers, you need to have
**enantiomerically enriched** starting materials. That is, materials
where the overwhelming majority of molecules have the same 3D
orientation in space. There are very few ways to generate this type of
chiral (handed) information from scratch: most enantiomerically pure
compounds are the result of biological processes, because amino
acids---and thus enzymes---exist as only one chiral form in biology.
However, certain kinds of starting materials can be prepared in
unnatural conditions using enzymes that are stolen from biology. One
such class of enzymes, the lipase, catalyzes either the conversion or
breakdown of esters into carboxylic acids (fatty acids, hence "lip"ase)
and free alcohols. The key to this kind of reaction when catalyzed by an
enzyme, is that it only acts on one mirror image of the starting
materials. One **enantiomer** is converted to an ester, and the other
remains as a free alcohol. The difference in polarity make them easy to
separate.

This kind of **chiral resolution** is a common process in pharmaceutical
manufacturing. The beauty of the process is the fact that the purity is
outstanding with typically \>99% of the compound with the desired 3D
arrangement. However, one complication may arise. Consider that enzymes
evolved in biological systems and thus aqueous environments. Most
building blocks of drug molecules are not actually soluble in water.
Believe it or not, many lipases can actually function just fine in a
nonpolar solvent such as hexane. Such molecules, even when "dry," hold
onto enough water molecules such that they can maintain their 3D shape
and functionality. The enzymes---as they swim around in the nonpolar
solvent---are embedded in a capsule of water (Figure (11.6)). This
environment follows the enzyme around wherever it goes in the nonpolar
medium. The hydrated lipase enzyme can thus be thought of as a nanorobot
or roving molecular assembler!

(Figure 11.6) 
>>>image(lipase.png.0)

Biocatalysis in industry and in the R&D laboratory is not limited to
lipase enzymes. That is, not every reaction involves the separation of
different enantiomers of alcohols. Modern tools of **genetic
engineering** and **directed evolution** can be used to design unnatural
enzymes to carry out a particular reaction. Whole organisms such as
yeasts can also be used as biocatalysts, e.g., for the enantioselective
conversion of carbonyl groups (as in Figure (11.6)b) into alcohols.
Biocatalytic systems can also be engineered---**biochemical
engineering**---to produce whole natural product molecules. Such an
approach often uses genetically engineered microorganisms. Engineers can
co-opt the biosynthetic, enzymatic pathways already present in the
microorganism for the production of useful and high-value molecules,
such as pharmaceutical precursors or even whole drug molecules.

### 11.2.4. Catalysts in environmental remediation

As we have seen, catalytic processes are required to affect all but the
simplest chemical reactions, or at least in affecting them in any kind
of reasonable timescale. Sometimes catalysts are used not in the
production of useful chemicals, but for the de-toxification of unwanted
byproducts. Nanostructured catalytic particles and surfaces with
nanostructures can have such a high ratio of surface area to volume that
they can even be used to react with toxic gases in real time. In fact,
the economic sectors of heavy industry and transportation would leave
the atmosphere a toxic mess were it not for nanoscopic bits of metal
that act as catalysts. Consider the **scrubbers** that remove toxic
compounds from flue gas (industrial exhaust). One such implementation of
this type of nano-enabled environmental remediation is in the area of
**catalytic converters** found in cars, construction vehicles, and other
heavy equipment.

#### Catalytic converters

When gasoline is combusted in an automobile engine, the ideal products
are carbon dioxide and water.

$$\text{C}_{n}\text{H}_{2n+2} + n\text{O}_2 = n\text{CO}_{2} + \text{H}_{2}\text{O}$$

However, reality is seldom ideal. Nearly always, what gets produced is a
mixture of, sure, mostly carbon dioxide and water, but also unreacted or
partially reacted hydrocarbons, incompletely oxidized carbon in the form
of carbon monoxide (CO), and products involving oxidized nitrogen
(NO$_{x}$, pronounced "nox"). Of these chemicals, unreacted hydrocarbons
contribute to global warming much more on a gram-per-gram basis than
does carbon dioxide. Next, carbon monoxide is toxic to humans[^11.2.5].
Finally, release of NO$_{x}$, consisting of NO and NO$_{2}$, along with
CO, drives atmospheric pollution.

These compounds themselves (with the exception perhaps of carbon
monoxide) are not particularly harmful. However, they are the starting
points for the formation of other pollutants. In particular, a cascade
of chemical reactions involving these starting materials, when combined
with sunlight and naturally occurring volatile organic compounds (VOCs),
produce acid rain, ground-level ozone, and smog. Smog---a *portmanteau*
of "smoke" and "fog"---contains a large fraction of particulate matter
(PM). These structures, especially with sizes of 2.5 $\mu$m or less ("PM
2.5"), are particularly hazardous. These micron and nanometer scale
particles can form from the combustion of solid material in the open air
(forest fires, electricity production from coal, burned biomass, or
fireplace fires) or from the polymerization or aggregation of VOCs
activated ultimately by NO$_{x}$, CO, and sunlight. Exposure to
atmospheric pollution---especially PM 2.5---is responsible for millions
of premature deaths per year, worldwide.

Given that much of this deleterious effect on lifespan is the result of
human activity, society has implicitly accepted such risks as a matter
of normal economic activity and growth. However, there are some things
that technology can do to mitigate these risks. One of the greatest
additions to the **internal combustion engine**---and indeed gas-driven
turbines used for electricity generation and industrial uses---is the
**catalytic converter**. In a "three-way" catalytic converter,
hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide are chemically oxidized fully, up to
CO$_{2}$, while NO$_{x}$ is reduced to N$_{2}$ in the presence of
carbon, hydrocarbons, or carbon monoxide, which itself is oxidized up to
CO$_{2}$ in the process, see Figure (11.7).

(Figure 11.7) 
>>>image(catalytic converter.png.0)

The catalytic converter itself is a box with an arrangement of support
structures coated with inorganic ceramic particles. These particles,
called the **wash coat**, comprise alumina (Al$_2$O$_3$) and/or silica
(SiO$_2$). Once applied, the wash coat contains a nanoscopically rough
surface.[^11.2.6] This surface is used as the substrate for the support of
precious metal particles, which perform the actual catalytic work. In
particular, a mixture of palladium (oxidation reactions), rhodium
(reduction reactions), and platinum (oxidation or reduction reactions)
is used.[^11.2.7] The oxidation and reduction reactions are driven at high
temperature (a few hundred $^{\circ}$ C) and thus the converter is
placed relatively close to the exhaust manifold emanating from the
engine.

starting materials in a solvent that can dissolve both the
**substrate(s)** and the catalyst. Such catalysts are sometimes
**organometallic** molecules consisting of a metal center surrounded by
organic **ligands**. Often, these molecules are called **transition
metal complexes** because the metal atoms or ions are usually transition
metals (occupying that long stretch of the periodic table between the
alkali and alkali earth metals on the left, to the "main group" on the
right, which contains carbon, sulfur, oxygen, nitrogen, silicon, and so
forth). That is, they belong to the class of elements with incompletely
filled $d$ orbitals.[^11.2.1] See Figure (11.2) for examples of famous
catalysts based on transition metal complexes. Advantages of homogeneous
catalysts include high selectivity in terms of the type of chemical
reaction that occurs, where on the substrate molecule it occurs, and the
suppression of side reactions. This selectivity arises from the fact
that every catalyst molecule is identical. (In contrast, as we will see
below, the surfaces of heterogeneous catalysts have active sites which
can differ in structure from one to the next.)

(Figure 11.2) 
>>>image(transition metal complexes.png.0)

The scope of reactions that can be affected by homogeneous catalysts is
vast. For example, the formation of carbon-carbon bonds, the synthesis
of polymers (sometimes the catalyst also serves as the initiator), and
the transformation of one functional group to another. For example,
acids and/or bases---Arrhenius, Brønsted-Lowry, or Lewis
definition---catalyze nearly all transformations of carbonyl-containing
functional groups. One special power of homogeneous catalysts is the
ability to affect **stereoselective** reactions. That is, reactions
which can produce one or the other mirror image of a molecule.
Transition metal based catalysts often have **chiral ligands**, which
affect the direction from which the substrates may approach the
catalyst, and thus determine which **stereoisomer** is produced. Organic
catalysts---of which enzymes are a special type---also have this
property. See Figure (11.3) for examples of chiral molecules. That is,
molecules whose mirror images are actually different compounds because
they have different orientations in space.

(Figure 11.3) 
>>>image(enantiomers.png.0)

Homogeneous catalysts have one major drawback: they are difficult to
recover after the reaction. Whereas a heterogeneous catalyst is usually
a solid and can often be recovered simply by filtration, a homogeneous
catalyst is dissolved in solution and is difficult to separate from the
products and reactants. The difficulty in removing so as to reuse the
catalyst is compounded by the instability of the catalyst molecules.
That is, homogeneous catalysts with active sites containing transition
metal atoms or ions are often unstable to air and water. Thus, methods
of aqueous extraction are incompatible with this type of catalyst. In
fact, in most chemical processes involving homogeneous catalysts based
on metals, the catalyst is destroyed when the reaction is **quenched**
(meaning stoppage of the reaction by the addition of water, another a
polar solvent, or a specific chemical species which deactivates the
catalyst or the reactants). A homogeneous catalyst also generally
requires the use of a solvent, whereas heterogeneous systems can act
directly on neat liquids and mixtures of gases.

#### Heterogeneous catalysis

Heterogeneous catalysis means that there is more than one phase present
in the reaction mixture. The heterogeneous catalyst itself is usually a
solid, and can act upon substrates present in either the liquid (or
solution) or gas phase. Compared to the reactions affected by
homogeneous catalysts, the types of reactions brought about by
heterogeneous catalysts are somewhat more limited. For example,
oxidation and reduction reactions and simple functional group
transformations are relatively straightforward to accomplish. Highly
selective reactions---such as those that can synthesize only one mirror
image of a compound---are difficult to achieve. The lack of selectivity
comes from the random arrangement and shapes of active sites in
catalytic particles and surfaces. Whereas the shape of the active site
in every molecule of a homogeneous catalyst is identical, in a
heterogeneous catalyst, there is a range of shapes.

Nevertheless, the vast majority of transformations in chemical
manufacturing by sheer tonnage of products is accomplished using
heterogeneous processes. What heterogeneous catalysts lack in
selectivity and specificity, they make up for in recyclability and
throughput. For example, it is a simple matter to remove catalyst
particles from a suspension by filtration. Moreover, if the catalyst is
immobilized on the inside surface of a reaction vessel---as in a
catalytic converter in an automobile, see below---the catalyst need not
be removed at all. Under favorable circumstances, catalyst molecules
usually used in homogeneous settings can be immobilized on the surfaces
of polymeric microbeads. This approach preserves the selectivity of the
homogeneous catalyst with the recyclability of catalysts in
heterogeneous systems.

### 11.2.2. Chemical manufacturing

Catalysis is ubiquitous in chemical manufacturing. Almost no commodity
nor fine chemical compound (especially polymers, pharamaceuticals, and
other organic molecules) can be produced without the use of catalysts.
Products with useful levels of complexity just don't form on their own
without the lowering of the activation barriers by catalysts. In fact,
even most bulk, commodity chemicals (think mineral acids like sulfuric
acid) are produced using catalysts. Chemical "cracking" of longer-chain
hydrocarbons into shorter chain ones in the petrochemical industry is
performed using high heat and the use of catalysts. Carbon-carbon bonds
simply do not break by themselves, even if the products have lower
potential energy than the reactants. Such reactions are simply too slow,
because the activation energy barrier on the way from reactants to
products is too high.

Some of the industrial processes with the largest impacts on society are
in the form of chemical manufacturing using catalysts. Chemical refining
could not occur without significant help from catalysts. Polymers, along
with the chemical starting materials from which they arise, are
generated using catalytic processes. A synthetic drug molecule may have
been manufactured as the result of 10-20 synthetic steps, most of which
were catalyzed. However, one of the most important industrial process
produces a simple product---ammonia, NH$_3$---without which modern life
on planet earth would not be possible.

#### Haber-Bosch process

The element of nitrogen is required for nearly everything, from the
production of fertilizers in agriculture to the synthesis of nitric acid
for the manufacturing of explosives. However, most nitrogen is locked up
in the atmosphere as nitrogen gas, dinitrogen (N$_2$), one of the most
inert gases known. It might as well be a noble gas! For decades,
nitrogen was obtained from mineral salts such as niter (KNO$_3$).
Alternatively, it could be extracted from guano (literally, bat poop) in
tropical caves. With the spreading of the industrial revolution,
large-scale agriculture, and the need for weapons for World War I, the
demand for nitrogen atoms became intense.

It was in this climate that Fritz Haber invented what became known as
the **Haber Process**, which generates ammonia from dinitrogen and
hydrogen gas. In the first sequence of reactions, many of which employ
heterogeneous catalysts, hydrogen is generated. This hydrogen is reacted
(again with the help of heterogeneous catalysts) with dinitrogen from
the air to produce ammonia. Ammonia is a highly valuable product, as it
can be used as the nitrogen source for a wide range of chemical
transformations. It is such an important compound industrially that it
consumes a vast amount of the world's energy resources: 1 percent of the
energy and 1.5 percent of carbon dioxide emissions.

### 11.2.3. Catalysis in biology

Biology is the ultimate proof-of-concept for the power and versatility
of catalysis, and of nanoengineering more broadly. From simple starting
materials---carbon dioxide, nitrogen, oxygen, and energy from sunlight
(and in some cases hydrothermal vents in the deep ocean---all of
biological structure and diversity is achieved. Metabolism, sensation,
reproduction, self-healing, consciousness, creativity, and all other
animal characteristics are all ultimately products of biochemical
processes. Thus, biology itself serves as a model for what systems of
highly selective nanostructured catalysts can do.

#### Enzymes

In the 1980s, visionary scientist Dr. K. Eric Drexler envisioned a
future dominated by molecular assemblers---nanoscopic machines akin to
industrial robots, but which could assemble molecules and ultimately
materials and devices atom by atom. The idea of a molecular assembler
stirred the imagination of many readers and was really a boon to the
field of nanotechnology. However, the idea was met with derision by
others. For example, some chemists point to the fact that chemical
reactions are required to transfer one atom to another. Moreover, such
reactions are done routinely on the scale of many tonnes with high
selectivity. Physical chemist and Nobel laureate Richard Smalley pointed
to the "sticky fingers" of a molecular assembler, by which he meant that
it would be difficult to detach atoms from the assembler to the
substrate because of strong van der Waals interactions. The strongest
criticism, however, comes from biology, where catalysts based on folded
proteins and nucleic acids---**enzymes** and **ribozymes**---already
have many of the characteristics of molecular assemblers. We explore the
properties of this extraordinarily important class of catalysts, here.

Essentially all chemical transformations carried out inside biological
systems are made possible by enzymes.[^11.2.2] Enzymes are the primary type
of biological catalyst, and are made primarily of proteins. Like other
proteins, enzymes have a **primary structure** consisting of a sequence
of amino acids, a **secondary structures** consisting of
$\alpha$-helices and $\beta$-sheets, a **tertiary structure** consisting
of disulfide bonds between cysteine residues (called a cystine disulfide
bond), and a **quaternary structure** consisting of multiple polypeptide
subunits stuck together.

The part of the enzyme that binds the **substrate(s)** is called the
**active site**, Figure (11.4). The active site, as in any catalyst,
must immobilize the reactant(s), affect a chemical change, and then
release the products. Just like any catalyst, an enzyme might undergo a
conformational reorganization and/or chemical change during the process,
but such a change is temporary. The hallmark of a catalyst is that it is
unchanged before and after the reaction it facilitates, so that it can
be used again and again. The active site has a shape that is
complementary to the shape of the transition state between reactants and
products. Inside the active site, the range of chemical functionality
afforded by the backbone of a polypeptide chain and on the R groups of
the amino acids are exploited to the fullest extent possible. That is,
lone pairs of oxygen atoms in the carbonyl groups and N--H groups along
the backbone, formal negative charges of aspartate and glutamate
residues, and formal positive charges of lysine, arginine, and histidine
residues, can be used to bond electrostatically to substrates. These
interactions are used to immobilize reactants in the active site, but
also to bring them in a position where they are more likely to react to
form products.

(Figure 11.4) 
>>>image(active site.png.0)

We note that the electrostatic interactions between an enzyme and its
substrate(s) tend to be stronger than suggested by the van der Waals
component consisting of dipole-dipole interactions given in Chapter 2.
The reason is that van der Waals forces assume the freedom for the
molecules containing permanent dipoles to rotate. This free rotation has
the effect of reducing the overall interaction energy between molecules
with permanent dipoles. Hence, the dipole-dipole force depends on
temperature, as a greater temperature unlocks a greater range of
orientations that a dipole can adopt in an electric field. However, when
a molecule is immobilized by multiple electrostatic and steric
interactions---like a key in a lock---it is no longer able to rotate
freely. Elimination of free rotation makes the electrostatic
interactions dominate even the London dispersion interaction, which we
told you in Chapter 2 was the dominant component of the van der Waals
interaction for all but the smallest molecules with strong dipole
moments. Thus, once a substrate is in the active site, it is locked in
tightly.

One of the aspects of the active site which affects its ability to
catalyze reactions is its shape. As it happens, the shape of the active
site is complementary not to the reactant(s) or product(s), but rather
to the shape of the **transition state**. Remember, the purpose of an
enzyme---or any catalyst, for that matter---is to lower the potential
energy of the transition state. The energy of the transition state is
directly related to the speed of the reaction by the Arrhenius equation,
equation (11.1), below

(Equation 11.1) $$k=A\exp{\frac{-E_{a}}{RT}}$$

where $E_a$ is the activation energy. Thus, by making itself
complementary to the transition state, the total electrostatic potential
energy can be lowered and the reaction rate will increase. Figure (11.4)
shows a schematic diagram of the shape of the active site and its effect
on the electrostatic potential energy of the transition state. The rate
of reaction of an enzyme is often characterized by the method of
Michaelis and Menten: Michaelis-Menten kinetics. While we will not go
into the topic here, you will learn all about it if you take a course in
biochemistry.

#### Industrial biocatalysis

Biological enzymes are used ubiquitously in industrial processes. One
example we will highlight is in **chiral resolution**. For example, the
enzyme lipase[^11.2.3] catalyzes the formation of ester bonds from carboxylic
acids and hydroxyl groups. When I (Darren) was an undergraduate
researcher, my project was to synthesize a natural product called
"basiliskamide A." This molecule was originally isolated from a
bacterium that lived inside a sea sponge (or something) off the coast of
Papua New Guinea. When new natural products are discovered, they are
often screened against an array of bacteria and other disease targets.
Basiliskamide A (Figure (11.5), along with its related isomer,
basiliskamide B) was found to have activity against two types of
fungi---*Aspergillus fumigatus* and *Candida albicans*. These two fungi
are not very dangerous to people with healthy immune systems (*C
albicans* causes diaper rash, which we've all had at some point in our
lives), but for those with weakened immune systems (e.g., HIV-AIDS
patients, chemotherapy patients, etc.), infections can be deadly.

(Figure 11.5) 
>>>image(basiliskamides.png.0)

Basiliskamide a is a pretty small, unassuming natural product. You
wouldn't base an entire PhD thesis on making it from scratch. But, it
was a good project for an undergraduate. However, there was a highly
challenging aspect to the synthesis. Namely, the series of four
**stereogenic centers** located in the red box in Figure (11.5). The
laboratory in which I did my undergraduate research specialized in
making these linear sequences of **stereogenic** carbon atoms.[^11.2.4] All
the atoms need to be attached in precisely the right way, otherwise the
molecule will cease to have its biological activity.

In order to generate stereogenic centers, you need to have
**enantiomerically enriched** starting materials. That is, materials
where the overwhelming majority of molecules have the same 3D
orientation in space. There are very few ways to generate this type of
chiral (handed) information from scratch: most enantiomerically pure
compounds are the result of biological processes, because amino
acids---and thus enzymes---exist as only one chiral form in biology.
However, certain kinds of starting materials can be prepared in
unnatural conditions using enzymes that are stolen from biology. One
such class of enzymes, the lipase, catalyzes either the conversion or
breakdown of esters into carboxylic acids (fatty acids, hence "lip"ase)
and free alcohols. The key to this kind of reaction when catalyzed by an
enzyme, is that it only acts on one mirror image of the starting
materials. One **enantiomer** is converted to an ester, and the other
remains as a free alcohol. The difference in polarity make them easy to
separate.

This kind of **chiral resolution** is a common process in pharmaceutical
manufacturing. The beauty of the process is the fact that the purity is
outstanding with typically \>99% of the compound with the desired 3D
arrangement. However, one complication may arise. Consider that enzymes
evolved in biological systems and thus aqueous environments. Most
building blocks of drug molecules are not actually soluble in water.
Believe it or not, many lipases can actually function just fine in a
nonpolar solvent such as hexane. Such molecules, even when "dry," hold
onto enough water molecules such that they can maintain their 3D shape
and functionality. The enzymes---as they swim around in the nonpolar
solvent---are embedded in a capsule of water (Figure (11.6)). This
environment follows the enzyme around wherever it goes in the nonpolar
medium. The hydrated lipase enzyme can thus be thought of as a nanorobot
or roving molecular assembler!

(Figure 11.6) 
>>>image(lipase.png.0)

Biocatalysis in industry and in the R&D laboratory is not limited to
lipase enzymes. That is, not every reaction involves the separation of
different enantiomers of alcohols. Modern tools of **genetic
engineering** and **directed evolution** can be used to design unnatural
enzymes to carry out a particular reaction. Whole organisms such as
yeasts can also be used as biocatalysts, e.g., for the enantioselective
conversion of carbonyl groups (as in Figure (11.6)b) into alcohols.
Biocatalytic systems can also be engineered---**biochemical
engineering**---to produce whole natural product molecules. Such an
approach often uses genetically engineered microorganisms. Engineers can
co-opt the biosynthetic, enzymatic pathways already present in the
microorganism for the production of useful and high-value molecules,
such as pharmaceutical precursors or even whole drug molecules.

### 11.2.4. Catalysts in environmental remediation

As we have seen, catalytic processes are required to affect all but the
simplest chemical reactions, or at least in affecting them in any kind
of reasonable timescale. Sometimes catalysts are used not in the
production of useful chemicals, but for the de-toxification of unwanted
byproducts. Nanostructured catalytic particles and surfaces with
nanostructures can have such a high ratio of surface area to volume that
they can even be used to react with toxic gases in real time. In fact,
the economic sectors of heavy industry and transportation would leave
the atmosphere a toxic mess were it not for nanoscopic bits of metal
that act as catalysts. Consider the **scrubbers** that remove toxic
compounds from flue gas (industrial exhaust). One such implementation of
this type of nano-enabled environmental remediation is in the area of
**catalytic converters** found in cars, construction vehicles, and other
heavy equipment.

#### Catalytic converters

When gasoline is combusted in an automobile engine, the ideal products
are carbon dioxide and water.

$$\text{C}_{n}\text{H}_{2n+2} + n\text{O}_2 = n\text{CO}_{2} + \text{H}_{2}\text{O}$$

However, reality is seldom ideal. Nearly always, what gets produced is a
mixture of, sure, mostly carbon dioxide and water, but also unreacted or
partially reacted hydrocarbons, incompletely oxidized carbon in the form
of carbon monoxide (CO), and products involving oxidized nitrogen
(NO$_{x}$, pronounced "nox"). Of these chemicals, unreacted hydrocarbons
contribute to global warming much more on a gram-per-gram basis than
does carbon dioxide. Next, carbon monoxide is toxic to humans[^11.2.5].
Finally, release of NO$_{x}$, consisting of NO and NO$_{2}$, along with
CO, drives atmospheric pollution.

These compounds themselves (with the exception perhaps of carbon
monoxide) are not particularly harmful. However, they are the starting
points for the formation of other pollutants. In particular, a cascade
of chemical reactions involving these starting materials, when combined
with sunlight and naturally occurring volatile organic compounds (VOCs),
produce acid rain, ground-level ozone, and smog. Smog---a *portmanteau*
of "smoke" and "fog"---contains a large fraction of particulate matter
(PM). These structures, especially with sizes of 2.5 $\mu$m or less ("PM
2.5"), are particularly hazardous. These micron and nanometer scale
particles can form from the combustion of solid material in the open air
(forest fires, electricity production from coal, burned biomass, or
fireplace fires) or from the polymerization or aggregation of VOCs
activated ultimately by NO$_{x}$, CO, and sunlight. Exposure to
atmospheric pollution---especially PM 2.5---is responsible for millions
of premature deaths per year, worldwide.

Given that much of this deleterious effect on lifespan is the result of
human activity, society has implicitly accepted such risks as a matter
of normal economic activity and growth. However, there are some things
that technology can do to mitigate these risks. One of the greatest
additions to the **internal combustion engine**---and indeed gas-driven
turbines used for electricity generation and industrial uses---is the
**catalytic converter**. In a "three-way" catalytic converter,
hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide are chemically oxidized fully, up to
CO$_{2}$, while NO$_{x}$ is reduced to N$_{2}$ in the presence of
carbon, hydrocarbons, or carbon monoxide, which itself is oxidized up to
CO$_{2}$ in the process, see Figure (11.7).

(Figure 11.7) 
>>>image(catalytic converter.png.0)

The catalytic converter itself is a box with an arrangement of support
structures coated with inorganic ceramic particles. These particles,
called the **wash coat**, comprise alumina (Al$_2$O$_3$) and/or silica
(SiO$_2$). Once applied, the wash coat contains a nanoscopically rough
surface.[^11.2.6] This surface is used as the substrate for the support of
precious metal particles, which perform the actual catalytic work. In
particular, a mixture of palladium (oxidation reactions), rhodium
(reduction reactions), and platinum (oxidation or reduction reactions)
is used.[^11.2.7] The oxidation and reduction reactions are driven at high
temperature (a few hundred $^{\circ}$ C) and thus the converter is
placed relatively close to the exhaust manifold emanating from the
engine.

#### Section 2: Catalysis
Catalysis, as you may remember from your high school chemistry class, is
the process by which a chemical reaction is sped up. In particular, in a
catalytic process, the **activation energy** of a chemical reaction is
reduced. The activation energy is the "hill" of potential
energy---analogous to how your gravitational potential energy rises when
you climb a hill---that a reaction "passes over" on its way from
reactants to products. This reduction in activation energy leads to an
accelerated reaction rate compared to the rate of the uncatalyzed
reaction. Critically, the potential energies of the products and
reactants are the same; all that changes is the pathway to get there
(see Figure (11.1)). Catalysts work by making one or both components
more reactive, stabilizing the transition state, or bringing the
reactants in close proximity. Catalysts are also sometimes chemically
altered in the process, though this alteration is temporary. Catalysts
are typically used in a sub-stoichiometric amount, meaning a **loading**
of a few percent or less, compared to the number of molecules of the
reactants. Catalysts can be used in such small loadings since a single
catalyst molecule or catalytic site on a surface can be used again and
again. The number that quantifies the number of reactions affected by a
catalyst is the **turnover number**.

(Figure 11.1) 
>>>image(catalysis.png.0)

### 11.2.1. Homogeneous vs. heterogeneous catalysis

Catalysts can be literally any chemical species, from a reactive site in
a porous mineral to a large enzyme. Even a single proton can be a
catalyst. In attempting to classify the broad range of molecules and
materials that have catalytic function, the first distinction can be
made by whether they are dissolved in solution---**homogeneous
catalysts**---or supported by a solid surface or
particle---**heterogeneous catalysts**. Biological catalysts---generally
enzymes---share features of both homogeneous and heterogeneous
catalysts, and are often treated as occupying a third category.

#### Homogeneous catalysis

Homogeneous catalysts largely consist of isolated atomic and molecular
species. They include protons, organocatalysts, and transition metal
complexes. They are added to the reaction mixture along with the
starting materials in a solvent that can dissolve both the
**substrate(s)** and the catalyst. Such catalysts are sometimes
**organometallic** molecules consisting of a metal center surrounded by
organic **ligands**. Often, these molecules are called **transition
metal complexes** because the metal atoms or ions are usually transition
metals (occupying that long stretch of the periodic table between the
alkali and alkali earth metals on the left, to the "main group" on the
right, which contains carbon, sulfur, oxygen, nitrogen, silicon, and so
forth). That is, they belong to the class of elements with incompletely
filled $d$ orbitals.[^11.2.1] See Figure (11.2) for examples of famous
catalysts based on transition metal complexes. Advantages of homogeneous
catalysts include high selectivity in terms of the type of chemical
reaction that occurs, where on the substrate molecule it occurs, and the
suppression of side reactions. This selectivity arises from the fact
that every catalyst molecule is identical. (In contrast, as we will see
below, the surfaces of heterogeneous catalysts have active sites which
can differ in structure from one to the next.)

(Figure 11.2) 
>>>image(transition metal complexes.png.0)

The scope of reactions that can be affected by homogeneous catalysts is
vast. For example, the formation of carbon-carbon bonds, the synthesis
of polymers (sometimes the catalyst also serves as the initiator), and
the transformation of one functional group to another. For example,
acids and/or bases---Arrhenius, Brønsted-Lowry, or Lewis
definition---catalyze nearly all transformations of carbonyl-containing
functional groups. One special power of homogeneous catalysts is the
ability to affect **stereoselective** reactions. That is, reactions
which can produce one or the other mirror image of a molecule.
Transition metal based catalysts often have **chiral ligands**, which
affect the direction from which the substrates may approach the
catalyst, and thus determine which **stereoisomer** is produced. Organic
catalysts---of which enzymes are a special type---also have this
property. See Figure (11.3) for examples of chiral molecules. That is,
molecules whose mirror images are actually different compounds because
they have different orientations in space.

(Figure 11.3)
